data.title: What the cast of the Spooks did next, from Pride and Prejudice to The Batman with Robert Pattinson
data.meta_description: One even had a part in Frozen - but not the Disney version
data.text:
When you hear the word, Spooks it is probably closely followed by that opening melody of 'dun dun, dundundun' playing in your head.

The much-loved London espionage drama picked up an army of fans during its 10 series.

It makes us feel old to think the first episode aired 19 years ago in 2002.

Though if you gave in to temptation and binge-watched the MI5 drama on iPlayer during lockdown, you'll know the show has stood the test of time, even if some of the tech is a bit dated.

Like a lot of spy dramas, the body count has been rather high.

Spoiler alert, fans were horrified when much-loved characters such as Adam Carter, Jo Portman and even tech operative Colin Wells, were killed off in high octane operations.

I don’t need to talk about the famous chip pan fat fryer scene for you to get who I am talking about.

After the show, the actors who played the iconic roles went on to do all sorts of different things.

Let’s take a look at what they have been up to since the show ended in 2011.

Peter Firth

The firm but respected head of section D counter-terrorism department, Harry Pearce was not to be messed with.

The experienced former field agent for MI6 was exactly the type of person you would want in charge during a crisis, but my God did he see a lot of his colleagues killed.

The divorced dad of two, with a soft spot for Ruth Evershed which later blossomed into love, was played by Yorkshireman Peter Firth.

The actor, who can do an impressive London accent, went on to star in BBC period drama Dickensian, ITV’s Regal series Victoria and also had a stint in Law & Order: Special Victims Unit.

He also reprised his spy role for the 2015 film Spooks: The Greater Good, though we can’t imagine a world where Harry and Ruth are not together.

In real life, he has been married three times and has four children.

Nicola Walker

The brainy senior Intelligence Analyst Ruth Evershed, played by Nicola Walker, was fluent in eight languages - though her Cantonese was famously 'horrible' - and was a core member of the team.

She joined in series 2 as a GCHQ spy but became a trusted member of section D working out obscure connections and helping the operatives save the day.

Her character was unlucky in love, to say the least, and after lame dates, her eventual husband was killed. Her office romance with Harry took a long time to build but when the timing was finally right, and they agreed to leave the service and retire together, disaster struck,

The son of Harry’s former lover dramatically stabbed her on the edge of a hill.

It was pretty emotional seeing such a beautiful landscape juxtaposed against Ruth collapsing in her partner’s arms - damn you BBC for taking us on this rollercoaster!

It still brings tears to our eyes today, remembering Harry visiting the house where they were going to move to after she died.

Nicola Walker took a break from the series in 2006 to have a baby before returning in 2009.

She has since gone on to take the lead role of DCI Cassie Stuart in Unforgotten, played Gillian Greenwood in the Last Tango in Halifax and even voiced the part of Síle de Tansarville in the video game Witcher 2 and 3.

The Stepney-born actress is married to fellow thespian Barnaby Kay and together they share a son, Harry, about whom we wonder whether he was named after the legendary Mr Pearce.

Matthew Macfadyen

Chief of section D, Matthew Macfadyen's Tom Quinn was known for his brooding leadership and calm strategic planning.

Both a blessing and a curse, he was deeply analytical, which caused him to eventually question the brutal aspects of his job.

After an explosive two seasons, in which he was framed for murder, wounded Harry and led a life on the run as a homeless person, he finally cleared his name.

By after he was reinstated at Thames House, he had a mental breakdown after battling thoughts about the so-called greater good he was fighting for.

His dating life was equally complicated and he went out with a single mum, before his work put her child at risk, then dated a CIA worker he was professionally often in conflict with.

Unlike lots of other key characters, however, he did not leave in a body bag and left the service on two feet.

But it wasn’t the last time audiences would see Matthew in the role and he returned for a cameo part in the final episode of series 10, much to the delight of fans.

Matthew met his wife on the show, Ashes to Ashes star Keely Hawkes.

They married in 2004 and went on to have two children together, with Matthew becoming stepfather to her son from a previous marriage.

Today the 46-year-old, who was born in Great Yarmouth, has gone on to some pretty impressive roles.

As well as starring in Succession, he played an unforgettable Mr Darcy for an adaptation of Pride and Prejudice.

Rupert Penry-Jones

A crush for a lot of people watching the show, Rupert Penry-Jones' charismatic Adam Carter took over section D after Tom’s departure.

Although fans took a while to warm up to him.

He was very different from his predecessor and brought with him experience as an M16 agent.

The married father of one also showed what it was like to have a family while protecting the capital from the threat of terrorism.

But as his son went to boarding school, the couple didn’t have to worry themselves about last minute child care plans when a bomb was about to go off in London.

However, they did play with fire, jointly taking part in dangerous missions that could have easily ended in death.

One such operation did go wrong for his on-screen wife Fiona, and a plot involving her former husband eventually ended in her demise.

He continued to work and hired a nanny who he briefly dated, but suffered from nightmares about his dead wife and wished he could have died instead.

He also has romantic relations with the wife of the Iranian Special Consul, Dariush Bakhshi and colleague Ros Myers.

He gets more and more reckless as the series progresses especially after a member of his team has been tortured and another was raped,

In an explosive exit, which was voted fourth most shocking death in the series by Radio Times readers, he was blown up in a car bomb, leaving Wes an orphan.

Rupert Penry-Jones went on to star in much loved legal drama Silk taking the part of Clive Reader and took the lead role as a detective inspector in Whitechapel.

He has big things planned for 2022 and will star alongside Robert Patterson in The Batman movie.

Keely Hawes

Oxford graduate Zoe Reynolds, played by Keely Hawes, had a keen linguistic ability and joined the team as a junior case officer at the start of the show.

She moved in with colleague Danny Hunter and although they had a brother and sister love-hate relationship, there were underlying romantic tensions at the time.

This came to the foreground when she met and became engaged to photographer Will North.

However just as she had risen the ranks at Thames House and found the man of her dreams it all went a bit wrong. Can't one MI5 character ride off into the sunset? Ok we know, we know!

She was found guilty in court with conspiracy to commit murder and was sentenced to 10 years in prison.

Her team stepped in and arranged for her to secretly escape to Chile instead of spending a decade behind bars.

Danny put all his ill-feeling towards her fiance behind him and took a risk telling Will where she was.

The couple rejoined and sent him a postcard from South America.

Actress Keely Hawes who went on to become a firm favourite in British drama series.

She appeared in Ashes to Ashes, The Bodyguard, Line of Duty and The Missing.

Married to Matthew Macfadyen, she has one child from a previous relationship and another two with her co-star.

David Oyelowo

The well-dressed analyst with a penchant for leather jackets, David Oyelowo's Danny Hunter excelled in high-pressurised environments.

He got into a little trouble with finances early on but more than made up for it by the second series when he went undercover as a trader.

He met his end on the show after being captured along with colleague Fiona Carter by Iraqi terrorists.

When they try to escape and kill one of their captors, the leader declares that one of them must die.

He gives the choice to section D leader Adam, who is married to Fiona and rings him up on the phone.

After saying a prayer, Danny provokes the terrorist to save his colleagues from making the awful decision.

He is then shot in the head.

His team arrives on the scene and Ruth cradles him but there is nothing anyone can do.

After Spooks, David Oyelowo took parts in The Good Wife, Selma, United Kingdom, Planet of the Apes and Jack Reacher.

He is married to fellow actress Jessica and the couple live with their four children in Los Angeles.

Richard Armitage

Richard Armitage's character Lucas North is brought into the show in series seven and he has an impressive backstory.

The former head of section D before Tom, he was imprisoned during an operation in Russia and brought back to the UK after eight years behind bars.

Having once been the best in the field, viewers were not sure whether the character should be trusted or was working as a double agent.

He found it hard adjusting to his old life and would have flashbacks about being tortured (although he kept it hidden from his team) and emotional fall out from talking to his ex-wife

Although Lucas works hard at getting section D to trust him, he doesn't always follow the rules but manages to toes the line till season eight when he comes into contact with one of his former interrogators from prison.

Juggling these emotions along with new CIA flame Sarah Caufield proves troublesome.

Series nine is where he really becomes undone and after a colleague's death (yes another one) his dark past and former lover is revealed.

He leaves the show after jumping off a tall building in front of Harry.

Armitage, went on to star in Captain America, The Hobbit, Frozen (not the Disney version) and has appeared in many plays on the stage.

Hermione Norris

Former MI6 agent Ros Myers, played by Hermione Norris, joins section D in the fifth series after learning her father Sir Jocelyn Myers is funding a conspiracy.

She helps the team foil the plot and is offered a job by Adam.

Quite cold and pragmatic, Ros will do whatever it takes to get the job done, keeping her emotions locked inside.

While on a rescue mission she is kidnapped by Yalta which is opposed to American hegemony and they torture her before recruiting her.

They also brainwash her into thinking the US is manipulating the UK during peal deals with Iran.

When the CIA starts killing off members of the group, Ros admits to section D she has been working for them but says she want to help bring them down.

In trues Spooks style she is injected with poison by a high-ranking Yalta member, but not all is as it seems.

Adams managers to switch the jab with a sedative and she goes on exile to Russia while her colleague holds a fake funeral for her.

For more news and features about London directly to your inbox sign up to our newsletter here.

However her death does eventually take place on the show, and after she has been reinstated into section D she later dies in a hotel bomb.

After leaving the show, Norris appeared in Doctor Who, Luther and Agatha Raisin and the Quiche of Death.

Before joining the programme, the 54-year old was already well known for her role in Cold Feet and Wire in the Blood.

She married writer Simon Wheeler and the couple share two children.

Miranda Raison

Aspiring journalist Jo Portman, played by Miranda Raison, was recruited by Adam in the fifth series after their lives crossed paths and she correctly deduced that he wasn’t just a simple gas engineer.

After earning his respect she is offered an entry-level job and undergoes training before accepting a position on the grid.

As a newbie, she spends a lot of time in the office at first, but is soon sent out on important missions and builds up her experience.

Fans thought she was killed off after being raped and tortured in series 6, but it turns out she was playing dead.

She struggles with post-traumatic stress throughout series 7 and gets a new short hair cut.

She forms a friendship with Ros, who she opens up to.

Jo goes from strength to strength however the character does not make it through many more episodes.

She is killed in series 8 after Ros shoots a terrorist and the bullet passes through their body and hits the operative at close range.

After leaving the show, Miranda Raison starred in Match Point, Doctor Who and Murder on the Orient Express.

She married Spooks co-star Raza Jaffrey but after divorcing him two years later, she went on to wed Christopher Mollard who she shares a child with.
